IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8731 S1381-1169(13)00150-7 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.04.012 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns for BiVO4 catalysts obtained at (a) pH=2 and (b) pH=9 after different thermal treatments. Fig. 2 Raman spectra for BiVO4 catalysts obtained at (a) pH=2 and (b) pH=9 after different thermal treatments. Fig. 3 SEM images of BiVO4 catalysts obtained at pH=2 by means of the following thermal treatment: (a) NH; (b) 100°C, 20h; (c) 140°C, 20h; and (d) 180°C, 20h. Fig. 4 SEM images of BiVO4 catalysts obtained at pH=9 by means of the following thermal treatment: (a) NH; (b) 100°C, 20h; (c) 140°C, 20h; and (d) 180°C, 20h. Fig. 5 Evolution of MB with photodegradation time for different BiVO4 catalysts obtained at (a) pH=2 and (b) pH=9. Fig. 6 Evolution of RhB with photodegradation time for different BiVO4 catalysts obtained at (a) pH=2 and (b) pH=9. Fig. 7 Evolution of ζ-potential of BiVO4 catalysts obtained at pH=2 and pH=9 after hydrothermal treatment at 140°C for 20h. Fig. 8 Evolution of RhB with photodegradation time for H2_140 and H9_140 BiVO4 photocatalysts at (a) natural pH 5.5 of RhB solution and (b) pH 3.5 acidified by means of HClO4. Obregón G. Colón * Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Sevilla, Centro Mixto Universidad de Sevilla CSIC, C/Américo Vespucio 49, 41092 Sevilla, Spain Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Sevilla, Centro Mixto Universidad de Sevilla CSIC C/Américo Vespucio 49 Sevilla 41092 Spain * Corresponding author. Tel.: +34 954489536. Graphical abstract BiVO4 hierarchical structures were synthesized by means of a surfactant free hydrothermal method having good photoactivities for the degradation of Methylene Blue and Rhodamine B under UV–vis irradiation. From the structural and morphological characterization it has been stated that BiVO4 present the monoclinic crystalline phase with different morphologies depending on the pH value. For Methylene Blue the photodegradation rate is strongly affected by the crystallite size and higher (004) facet exposition. On the contrary, for Rhodamine B, the ζ-potential of the surface clearly determines the photocatalytic performance of BiVO4 catalyst. Keywords BiVO4 Photocatalysis ζ-Potential Isoelectric point Methylene Blue Rhodamine B 1 Introduction It is widely accepted that heterogeneous photocatalytic technology is a firm alternative for the degradation of organic pollutants [1,2]. Nowadays, the environmental problems demand increasingly severe regulations that open up opportunities for novel green photocatalytic routes leading to the alternative materials to traditional TiO2. These alternative photocatalytic materials pursue the utilization of solar light as efficient as possible. For this scope, different strategies have been traditionally followed, based on all cases in the improvement of visible photon absorption. Among these, the modification of TiO2 by cationic or anionic doping or coupling TiO2 with other semiconductors with low band gaps have been proved to be viable ways to allow the extension of light absorption edge [3–5]. Another option consists on the creation of new kind of semiconductors with band edge positions which allow visible absorption [6–9]. Among these new families of visible active photocatalysts, bismuth vanadate has been widely reported exhibiting good photocatalytic properties [2]. BiVO4 was firstly suggested by Kudo et al. and is considered a promising visible light-active semiconductor with a fairly strong oxidation power [10–12]. Bismuth vanadate (BiVO4) has three main crystalline structures: zircon-tetragonal, scheelite-tetragonal and scheelite-monoclinic. BiVO4 can be synthesized by different preparation routes which allow obtaining selectively one of the mentioned structures depending on the preparation method. It has been reported that the photocatalytic activity of BiVO4 is also closely related to the phase structures, being the scheelite-monoclinic one the most active [2]. The photoactive monoclinic structure is usually obtained by means of high temperature methods. Meanwhile, the tetragonal form is normally achieved by aqueous media methods at low temperature process. The use of hydrothermal treatments for the preparation of BiVO4 leads to the appearance of the monoclinic phase at mild temperatures with lower crystallite sizes with respect to those obtained from solid state reaction [13,14]. A large number of preparation techniques have been investigated which include solid state [15], combustion [16], aqueous processes such as hydrothermal [17], polymer assisted coprecipitation [18], flame process [19], and spray pyrolysis [20]. From this huge variety of synthetic techniques it has been stated that the photocatalytic behaviour of BiVO4 is strongly dependent on its 3D morphologies and microstructures [21–27]. In a previous paper, we proposed the preparation of BiVO4 hierarchical heterostructures synthesized by means of a surfactant free hydrothermal method having good photoactivities for the degradation of Methylene Blue under UV–vis irradiation [23]. In this study we focused our attention in the effect of the precipitating agent, pH and hydrothermal time on the crystallization and morphology. Now, we report the effect of temperature of the hydrothermal method which allows obtaining BiVO4 monoclinic systems with controlled morphology. The relationship between surface area, structure and morphology with the further photocatalytic activity for Methylene Blue (MB) and Rhodamine B (RhB) degradation has been also performed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of photocatalysts The preparation of Bi-based photocatalysts was carried out using the corresponding amounts of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, and NH4VO3 as precursors. Thus, 5mmol of Bi precursor was dissolved in 10mL of glacial acetic acid while the stoichiometric amount of NH4VO3 (5mmol) was dissolved in 60mL of bidistilled water. These two solutions were finally mixed to form a yellowish suspension (pH~2) which was kept under stirring for 1h. Then, the resulting suspension was transferred into a Teflon recipient inside of stainless steel autoclave. The hydrothermal treatment was performed at 100°C, 140°C and 180°C for 20h. The precipitate was then filtered, repeatedly washed and dried overnight at 120°C. Afterwards, thus obtained samples were submitted to a further calcination treatment at 300°C for 2h. Similarly, a second set of catalysts was prepared at pH=9 by adding the appropriate amount of ammonia solution. Hydrothermal obtained catalysts were named as Hx_T where x and T denote the pH value and the hydrothermal temperature, respectively. In order to study the effect of hydrothermal time, samples obtained at 140°C were submitted to hydrothermal treatment for 72h. These samples were denoted as Hx_T_72. Non-hydrothermal system was obtained by filtration of initial suspension, thoroughly washed with water and drying overnight at 120°C. Then, a further calcination at 300°C for 2h was performed. These catalysts were named as NH_x, being x the pH value. 2.2 Materials characterization BET surface area and porosity measurements were carried out by N2 adsorption at 77K using a Micromeritics 2010 instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Siemens D-501 diffractometer with Ni filter and graphite monochromator. The X-ray source was Cu Kα radiation (0.15406nm). Crystallite sizes for BiVO4 catalysts were estimated from the line broadening of (112) X-ray diffraction peaks by using the XPert HighScore Plus software. Micro-Raman measurements were performed using a LabRAM Jobin Yvon spectrometer equipped with a microscope. Laser radiation (λ =532nm) was used as excitation source at 5mW. All measurements were recorded under the same conditions (1s of integration time and 30 accumulations) using a 100× magnification objective and a 125mm pinhole. The morphology of samples was followed by means of field emission-SEM (Hitachi S 4800). The samples were dispersed in ethanol using an ultrasonicator and dropped on a copper grid. UV–vis spectra were recorded by using a Shimadzu AV2101 in the diffuse reflectance mode (R) and transformed to a magnitude proportional to the extinction coefficient (K) through the Kubelka–Munk function, F(R ∞ ). Samples were mixed with BaSO4 that does not absorb in the UV–vis radiation range (white standard). Scans range was 250–800nm. The ζ potential of the photocatalysts was measured with a Zetamaster equipment (Malvern Instrument). Photocatalysts were dispersed in aqueous NaCl solution (10−2 M) at different pH values leaving in equilibrium overnight previous to the measure. 2.3 Photocatalytic experimental details The MB and RhB (Scheme 1 ) oxidation reactions were performed using a batch reactor (150mL) with a 200W Xenon lamp. The intensity of the incident light on the solution measured with a HD2302 photometer (Delta OHM) gives 124W/m2 using LP 471 UVA sensor (spectral response 315–400nm) and 524W/m2 using LP 471 RAD sensor (spectral response 400–1050nm). In the oxidation tests, an air flow was employed to produce a homogenous suspension of the photocatalyst in the solution. Before each experiment, the catalysts (1g/L) were settled in suspension with the reagent mixture for 15min. The blank experiment was performed without catalyst and no dye degradation was observed after 2h. The evolution of the initial MB (ca. 10ppm) and RhB (ca. 5ppm) concentration was followed through the evolution of the characteristic 664nm and 554nm bands, respectively, using a centrifuged aliquot ca. 2mL of the suspension (microcentrifuge Minispin, Eppendorf). The pH of the suspension was unchanged during the photodegradation tests (pH~6.5 and ~5.5 for Methylene Blue and Rhodamine B, respectively) for all BiVO4 samples. In both cases, for Rhodamine B as well as for Methylene Blue, the dye discoloration proceeds by chromophore cleavage since no significant shift was observed in their characteristic UV–vis bands followed the photoactivity studies. 3 Results and discussion The non-hydrothermal synthesis at acid conditions leads a mixture of tetragonal (PDF 14-0133, corresponding to the I41/amd space group) and monoclinic (PDF 83-1697, corresponding to the I2/b space group) BiVO4 structures. On the contrary, by increasing the pH value using ammonia a single phase scheelite BiVO4 with monoclinic structure was achieved (Fig. 1 ). Moreover, hydrothermal treatment leads to single monoclinic phase in both series, which is at H2 and H9. As expected, as hydrothermal temperature increases, the crystallite size progressively increases until hydrothermal temperature of 140°C (Table 1 ). Surprisingly, the hydrothermal treatment at 180°C leads to lower crystallite sizes in both series. Comparing the crystallite size of these two series, it can be noticed that the preparation at lower pH value seems to induce slightly higher crystallite sizes. It can be deduced that as the temperature increases, an improvement in the crystallinity is achieved without changing the crystalline structure, being more evident for H2 series. By observing the relationship between the different diffractions corresponding to (101), (004) and (020) planes, it is possible to infer for H2 series a clear preferential orientation for (004) plane (Table 1). On the contrary, for H9 series it appears that (020) plane exhibits a higher relative intensity with respect the theoretical one. At the same time the I (004)/I (112) ratio appears notably shrank. This effect was related with the anisotropic growth of the particles which showed an acicular morphology [23]. The preparation by a non-hydrothermal method leads to rather high surface area materials if we compare with hydrothermal series (Table 1). Moreover, the precipitation at high pH clearly produces a significantly higher specific surface area than for the sample prepared at pH=2 (29m2/g vs. 9m2/g). In contrast, hydrothermally treated samples exhibit a completely suppression of surface area. In this later case, these catalysts present surface areas lower than 2m2/g. It is possible to appreciate a slight decrease in surface area, inversely as crystallite size evolution, as hydrothermal temperature increases. Therefore, a quick sintering process is taking place as hydrothermal temperature rise above 100°C. By comparing the two set of samples obtained at different pH values, it can be notice that as in the case of the structural evolution, no significant differences can be highlighted regarding to the surface area values between both series. In Fig. 2 , we report the Raman spectra corresponding to the two set of BiVO4 samples. Raman bands around 158, 208, 324, 362, 710, and 826cm−1 were observed for all samples, which are typical vibrational bands of BiVO4 [28,29]. The band around 205cm−1 has been ascribed to the external mode of BiVO4, which gives little structural information. The Raman bands at 324 and 366cm−1 are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric deformation modes of the VO4 3− tetrahedron, respectively. Finally, the Raman bands at 822cm−1 corresponds to the symmetric VO stretching mode with Ag symmetry. This band exhibits a weak shoulder at about 706cm−1 assigned to the antisymmetric VO stretching mode with Bg. Franklin et al. reported an empirical expression to correlate the VO bond length with the Raman stretching frequencies [30]. Recently Kudo et al. also used this expression for correlating the VO bond length from the position of this Raman band [29]. It can be noticed that in both series for the samples obtained by a non-hydrothermal synthesis or at 100°C hydrothermal temperature, the position of the stretching mode band is slightly shifted towards lower values than those observed for higher hydrothermal temperature ones. This fact would indicate a rather higher VO distances for the samples prepared at such low temperature. It can be pointed out that BiVO4 samples exhibiting these higher VO distances also showed the higher BET surface areas. Thus, it can be assumed that the sintering process taking place at hydrothermal temperature higher than 100°C could be the reason of the shortening in the VO bond length. In addition, samples obtained by hydrothermal treatment clearly present more defined spectra due to lower band widths. The band narrowing of Raman spectra is closely related to the crystalline features [31]. Thus, it can be observed that the peaks in Raman spectra become narrow and sharp and therefore more defined, denoting that the crystallinity increases, the particle grows up, and the surface area decreases. This shift in the Bg band appears more obvious for H2 series, denoting the already mentioned more crystallinity of this series. As it has been extensively stated, the morphology of BiVO4 systems is notably sensitive to the preparation conditions [23,32]. It has been widely reported that synthetic parameters such as temperature, pH or use of templates strongly affect to the final morphology of the sample [2]. In Fig. 3 we show the evolution of the morphology with hydrothermal temperature within the two series studied. At lower pH (i.e. H2 series) the non-hydrothermal synthesis leads to a well-defined hierarchical structure (Fig. 3a). The initial sphere-like 3D structure seems to collapse upon hydrothermal treatment. As temperature treatment rises up the collapsed spheres progress towards polyhedral dense structure. The evolution clearly denotes a rapid sintering process and therefore an increase in crystallinity (Fig. 3b–d). From the initial hierarchical structure formed by small particles and exhibiting a high porosity and rather high surface area, the particles develop towards a compacted polyhedral structure. Regarding to H9 series, the non-hydrothermal sample exhibits a nanoparticulated structure formed by homogeneous roundish particles (Fig. 4 a). From this image it can be easily infer the high surface area obtained for this sample (ca. 29m2/g). As in the case of H2 series, the hydrothermal treatment clearly induces a strong change in the morphology, being in this case even more pronounced. Thus, a needle-like structured material can be observed for hydrothermal treatment along the different temperatures studied. The evolution with temperature clearly points out a progressive sintering of the initial aciculate particles. At higher temperature the needles seems to melt one to each other denoting the high sintering process attained. The observed morphology explain the preferential orientation observed by XRD [23]. Thus, the crystalline growth along the b axis to form the acicular particles leads to the extinction of the (040) diffraction line and the notably exaltation of diffraction lines corresponding to the planes (110) and (020). The photocatalytic performance of the as-prepared m-BiVO4 was evaluated by following the photodegradation of MB and RhB under UV–vis light irradiation (Figs. 5 and 6 ). From these results, it appears that all series showed degradation rates directly affected by the hydrothermal temperature. At the same time, it can be stated different photocatalytic behaviour of the series depending on the pollutant considered. For MB degradation better photocatalytic activity was found for H2 series, while for RhB degradation H9 series showed better reaction rates (Table 2 ). Considering the MB degradation, H9 series exhibited final conversion values ranged from 65% to 80% (Fig. 5). On the other hand, for H2 final conversions observed appear from 60% to 96%. This implies that H2 series presents better photocatalytic performances for this reaction. Non-hydrothermal samples NH2 and NH9 also showed quite different performance. Thus, while NH2 presents a high degree of pollutant adsorption (almost 90% of the dye remains adsorbed during the 15min previous to the reaction), no significant adsorption was observed for NH9. The high adsorption rate observed for NH2 would be related to its notably surface area [19]. However, the same explanation is not valid for NH9 which exhibited a higher surface area and a negligible MB adsorption. From these results appears that most photoactive sample was H2 hydrothermally treated at 140°C for 20h (Table 2). Increasing the time treatment from 20h to 72h at 140°C or the hydrothermal temperature to 180°C, a detrimental effect in the photocatalytic activity was observed. The origin of the different photocatalytic performance of these two series could be ascribed to the higher crystallinity showed by H2 series as well as to the higher exposition of (004) planes, which shows the larger atom density [33]. For the RhB degradation, lower final conversions were obtained for both series (Fig. 6). It has been reported that the point of zero charge (pzc) of BiVO4 is around 2.5 [19,34–36]. This would indicate that in the reaction media, the BiVO4 surface might be negatively charged. As MB has a cationic configuration, its adsorption would be favoured. Moreover, RhB is a cationic or neutral dye molecule depending on whether the carboxyl acid group is dissociated or not. The acid group in Rhodamine B would dissociate with increasing pH and a negative charge on the dye molecule might be considered (RCOO−). Thus, an electrostatic repulsion effect against the RhB molecules would take place, diminishing its photodegradation rate. In this case, better performances were obtained for H9 series with final conversions ranging 30–50%. For H2 series the conversions at the end of the reaction were always below 35%. This different behaviour could be related with the ζ-potential value of the catalysts at the reaction pH. It has been reported that the photoactivity and mechanism followed in the reaction are closely related to the isoelectric point (IEP) and the ζ-potential of BiVO4 [35]. In Fig. 7 we show the evolution of the ζ-potential with the pH value. Although the point of zero charge value is similar for the two samples studied (IEP =2.7 for H2_140 and IEP =3.0 for H9_140), the ζ-potential measured at the pH of the reaction media (ca. 5.5 for RhB solution) appeared rather different. As MB is cationic dye and at the reaction pH (ca. 6.5) the ζ-potential both series are not the limiting factor for the reactivity. Thus, while for H2_140 sample the surface exhibited a negative charge of ζ =−50mV, for H9_140 the ζ-potential lies ca. −30mV. This implies that the surface situation of both catalysts is rather different and the adsorption of the dye molecule would be affected by this fact. In fact, when we performed the degradation reaction of RhB at pH=3.5, for which ζ-potential are similar for both catalysts (ca. −5mV), the reaction progresses similarly for both samples (Fig. 8 ). Moreover, since the surface potential is in this case lower, it appears that the reaction rate for H2_140 catalyst is higher with respect to that at higher pH values (3.63×10−5 and 4.84×10−5 s−1 for pH=3.5 and pH=5.5, respectively), indicating and improvement in the photoactivity. Indeed the final conversion for this sample enhanced from 34% to 50% at this pH. For H9_140 catalyst it appears that no significant changes have been found in the photoactivity by lowering the reaction pH value. The origin of the different IEP for the two series studied could be associated in principle to the preferred exposition of planes observed for both series. As it was stated from XRD both series presented different preferred plane exposition, (004) for H2 and (200) for H9 series. These exposed planes would provide different surface charges and could be the responsible of the evolution of the ζ potential. It arises that this fact is most critical for RhB than for MB due to the double adsorption possibility of the former. 4 Conclusions We have obtained well crystallized m-BiVO4 by a simple surfactant free hydrothermal method. By changing the pH, directing agent and hydrothermal parameters such as temperature and time, different morphologies have been obtained. The best performance was clearly not associated to the surface area values, and is strongly affected by the crystallite size and morphology. For the different series obtained, better photocatalytic performances for MB degradation have been achieved for m-BiVO4 prepared at pH=2. It appears that the key parameter for this reaction is the crystallite size and the preferential (004) facet exposition. On the contrary, for RhB degradation it can be noted that the crucial factor is the ζ-potential of the surface. The evolution of the surface potential with the pH can be related to the different morphology and the subsequent preferred facet exposition of BiVO4. coredata.dc:description: BiVO4 hierarchical structures were synthesized by means of a surfactant free hydrothermal method having good photoactivities for the degradation of Methylene Blue and Rhodamine B under UV–vis irradiation. From the structural and morphological characterization it has been stated that BiVO4 present the monoclinic crystalline phase with different morphologies depending on the pH value. For Methylene Blue the photodegradation rate is strongly affected by the crystallite size and higher (004) facet exposition. On the contrary, for Rhodamine B, the ζ-potential of the surface clearly determines the photocatalytic performance of BiVO4 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: On the different photocatalytic performance of BiVO4 catalysts for Methylene Blue and Rhodamine B degradation
